Content:
Under ideal circumstances, if I wanted an event (for ex: `void OnSomethingHappened()`) that is defined in Class B  being handled the exact same way in all its subclasses (X, Y and Z in the diagram) I would just mod Class B so all its children would have the same behaviour for the given event and I would have one single point of maintenance for that. Now, __if I can't mod Class B__, is there a way to have the same event handling without having to repeat the exact same code in all subclasses? Note, __the event method is NOT defined in the superclass Class A__. 

So far, what I did as a solution for this problem is using association instead of inheritance: I coded the event handling into a separated object and called it from all Class B subclasses  (X, Y and Z). That way I don't have the bulk of the logic repeated, but I still have to repeatedly override the event method in each subclass of Class B and call the handling code defined in the aforementioned object. Does anyone knows a better solution for this scenario?
